7.text: Welcome to the second part of this three-part lecture

11.text: series that I'll be giving on telomeres and telomerase. In

14.text: part two, I'm going to discuss telomeres and telomerase in

18.text: human cells, and particularly I'm going to emphasize the

22.text: setting of cancer cells. Now you may recall from the first

27.text: lecture that the function of telomerase is to maintain the

31.text: telomeres and prevent them from shortening as cells

36.text: divide, because telomere shortening would otherwise

39.text: occur in the absence of telomerase, to compensate for

42.text: the shortening processes. And so, maintaining telomeres

46.text: allows the cells to keep on dividing. In human cells, we

54.text: can also see though that telomerase itself is protecting

58.text: telomeres, and so I want to show you one kind of

61.text: experiment for that. And the conclusion is going to be that

68.text: it's not just the bulk telomere length that matters, but the

71.text: presence of telomerase can determine whether a

75.text: telomere is seen by the cell as sufficiently long or not. The

81.text: experiment I'll show you was done in cultured human

85.text: cells. These were not cancer cells, and these were cells

88.text: that have normally extremely, extremely low levels of

91.text: telomerase, effectively, for our purposes, essentially no

95.text: measurable telomerase activity, and certainly their

97.text: telomeres are not maintained. Now I've shown you in very

100.text: simple diagrammatic form human telomerase, so this

104.text: would be the template sequence of the human

107.text: telomerase RNA, and this is the overhanging G-rich

113.text: strand. It's actually usually longer than this, but I've just

116.text: shown it as a simple diagrammatic form here. And this of

120.text: course is the duplex telomeric DNA that will be consisting

126.text: of hundreds or thousands of telomeric repeats, as you go

129.text: in toward the chromosome interior. And just as I showed

134.text: you for Tetrahymena telomerase, the template region is

137.text: copied, and so the DNA... for example, a DNA with three

142.text: Gs, two Ts, and an A, would sit down here on the

145.text: template, and then nucleotides would added, extending

148.text: along the template, thereby lengthening the DNA in this

154.text: reverse transcriptase reaction that telomerase carries out.

159.text: So what was done was to compare cells in which

163.text: telomerase was being expressed or not being expressed,

169.text: and look at the growth of the cells and the telomere

172.text: length. Now the protein TERT is the core protein that has

177.text: this enzymatic activity: the reverse transcriptase activity,

181.text: and probably other activities, as I will allude to. And so, in

186.text: these experiments, a particular mutation was made on the

191.text: TERT protein, it happened to be a very small change of a

193.text: few amino acids added to the very C-terminus, and what

198.text: this does is it doesn't affect the enzymatic activity, but it

202.text: does affect the ability of this enzyme to elongate

207.text: telomeres in cells, and it's called a hypomorph because

212.text: that refers to the fact that it has an insufficient function,

217.text: but it showed something useful. Now here's the

220.text: experiment, and I'm going to walk you through this rather

223.text: complex-looking slide. First of all, I want to show you a

227.text: growth curve of human fibroblasts in culture. What

231.text: normally happens is, if we look at the... this is cumulative

235.text: dilutions, which is just an operational term telling you how

237.text: many cell divisions are going on, and this is the number of

240.text: days. So if you culture human fibroblasts, normally what

244.text: you find is that the cells will continue to multiply for a

248.text: while, and then they'll cease multiplying any further, so the

251.text: curve flattens out, so you see they've undergone

254.text: something like 50 or so divisions. And if you put in a

259.text: control vector, which would be important, you get the

262.text: same curve. But if you put in the test vector, which

266.text: actually is expressing this form of the human telomerase

271.text: core protein TERT, because the fibroblast cells naturally

275.text: have enough telomerase RNA and the other components

278.text: of telomerase, all they're missing is the TERT, you just

280.text: have to add this in, and now you can restore telomerase

284.text: activity. But what's very interesting is the telomeres and

287.text: the cell growth. What you can see is, first of all, the cell

291.text: growth has been greatly extended. We've now made

294.text: these cells very much elongated in their lifespan

299.text: compared with the controls or the parental cells. Now let's

303.text: look at the telomeres. If we look at the telomeres in these

307.text: cells, the controls, we find that they're gradually becoming

312.text: somewhat shorter, and at this point here, they've pretty

315.text: much ceased to divide, so we're out here, they pretty

318.text: much cease dividing. So the telomeres on average are

321.text: about this long, and the cells have picked up the signal,

324.text: they've said the telomere length is shorter here than here,

328.text: and they've picked up the signal, and they've said we're

329.text: not going to divide any further. Now we've added the

332.text: hTERT. Now actually what happened was that, I told you

335.text: the cells continue to grow a long, long time. The

339.text: telomeres shorten, and then they steady out at some

343.text: much shorter length, so through here and through here,

346.text: they're actually growing quite well, but they're going with

348.text: much shorter telomeres. So in other words, these cells

355.text: can keep dividing for a long time with very short

358.text: telomeres, and the difference was they had telomerase

362.text: being expressed. So we used a trick just to separate out

366.text: the telomere lengthening property of telomerase from its

370.text: ability to stabilize telomeres, and we saw that in fact if you

373.text: have this telomerase present throughout, even though

377.text: the telomeres maintain short, they are perfectly stable,

381.text: and the cells can keep dividing. So this is the second

385.text: piece of evidence, I showed you the first piece of

389.text: evidence for you in yeast systems in the first part of this

393.text: lecture series, and now this is the second piece of

395.text: evidence that telomerase is having a protective function,

399.text: in this case, it's in human cells, and it's stabilizing

402.text: telomeres that otherwise would've been too short in its

405.text: absence. This is not unique to human cells, it's been seen

408.text: in yeast systems as well experimentally. So I just talked to

414.text: you about normal cells, and I told you that, in those

418.text: human fibroblasts grown in culture, there's very little

421.text: telomerase. So, now let's talk about where do we normally

430.text: find telomerase in human cells? Well, if you look in cells,

440.text: you find that it actually is on at times when the cells are

443.text: greatly proliferating during fetal development, and it does

446.text: remain active in certain proliferative cells. It's also found

451.text: active in stem cells, in cells that are activated to

455.text: proliferate, such as lymphocytes proliferating under the

461.text: response to, for example, a pathogen. One finds stem

467.text: cells, for example, in hair follicles; those have telomerase.

471.text: So one does find telomerase in cells that are stem cells

474.text: and various sorts of cells that are induced to proliferate.

482.text: And in fact in most other cells, one can find telomerase,

486.text: but it's in very low levels. So initially people thought there

490.text: was no telomerase in normal epithelial cells or fibroblasts

493.text: or endothelial cells, but closer scrutiny showed that in fact

497.text: there were real, definitely low and very downregulated,

501.text: but real levels of telomerase. And in the third part of this

509.text: three-lecture series, I will talk more about the telomerase

514.text: in the normal cells of people and tell you about some in

520.text: vivo studies that have been done. Now, cancer cells.

525.text: Cancer cells are infamous for their ability to keep on

530.text: multiplying. Now, they can do this for a variety of different

534.text: reasons. They lose their system of checks and balances

538.text: that prevent them from overmultiplying, and that's

541.text: because of a lot of genetic and epigenetic changes that

544.text: have taken place in their progression to become a

548.text: malignant cancer cell. Now, they are immortal cells, and

553.text: indeed, as you might expect, telomerase is on in these

556.text: cells, and in fact it's very high in the vast majority of

560.text: human cancers, particularly as they've got to the invasive

563.text: stages. And that makes a lot of sense based on what I

568.text: just told you, because if the cells are to keep on

571.text: multiplying, then they have to keep on replenishing their

574.text: telomeres. Now I'll you some more recent results in the

578.text: last few years, which also suggest telomerase may be

582.text: doing other things in human cancer cells. It is certainly

586.text: maintaining the telomeres, and that is important, but there

589.text: may be other functions as well. So I'll tell you some newer

592.text: findings about that. So, let's just recapitulate what I said

598.text: about where we find telomerase in humans. So it keeps

601.text: telomeres elongating and replenished, and therefore cells

604.text: can keep dividing in stem cells and, of course, I didn't

610.text: mention germ cells. Now of course we wouldn't be here if

613.text: we didn't have maintenance of telomeres from generation

616.text: to generation. Telomerase indeed is active in germ cells,

620.text: as well as stem cells of various kinds. As I said, it's

623.text: detectable in many normal cell types, and highly active in

627.text: the great majority of human cancers. And by the way, in

632.text: some of those human cancers in which you don't find the

635.text: high telomerase, one actually often finds this ALT

639.text: mechanism, but it's only a particular subset of cancers in

643.text: which one finds ALT being a prominent means of

647.text: maintaining telomeres. The great majority of the common

650.text: human tumors have highly active telomerase. So,

656.text: telomerase is highly active in human tumors. So one could

662.text: imagine inhibiting telomerase, and this might be a good

667.text: target for trying to inhibit the growth of cancer cells, if you

672.text: could inhibit telomerase in cancer cells. And so in

677.text: investigating this, some interesting things emerged. So

681.text: let's just think about what is expected to happen if you

684.text: don't have telomerase in the cancer cells. Well, as you

687.text: know, cells multiply, and their telomeres will progressively

691.text: become shorter and shorter if there isn't telomerase to

693.text: counteract that shortening, and so eventually when the

697.text: telomeres get too short, the cells would eventually cease

700.text: to divide, and the cells respond to those short telomeres

705.text: by either what's call the "senescence response," in which

709.text: the cells simply won't replicate their DNA anymore, or a

713.text: cell death response that can include an apoptotic

716.text: response, which involves an active cell suicide program

721.text: that can be induced by dysfunctional telomeres. Whether

725.text: it's senescence or cell death does depend upon the cell

729.text: type. So, the simple prediction, diagrammatically, would

734.text: be, if you didn't have telomerase, the cells now would

738.text: have shorter and shorter telomeres, and after some

740.text: number of divisions, eventually there would be cell death.

747.text: Without telomerase, it's been observed experimentally,

750.text: typically human cells lose their telomeric DNA at this kind

754.text: of rate. I've put 150-200 base pairs per cell division; that's

759.text: seen in a number of cultured cells and also in some

765.text: cancer cells in which telomerase has been inhibited.

768.text: Now, I told you that human telomeres are typically made

773.text: of hundreds, even thousands, of copies of telomeric

779.text: repeats, they're thousands of base pairs long, so at this

782.text: rate, it's going to take quite a lot of cell divisions before

786.text: the telomere gets short enough that the cells will have this

789.text: response. So that in fact is the prediction, and if you

795.text: inhibit the telomerase enzyme using, for example, a small

799.text: molecule inhibitor that inhibits the catalytic function of

804.text: telomerase that prevents it from carrying out that DNA

808.text: polymerase reaction by the reverse transcriptase

811.text: mechanism, if you inhibit telomerase in such a way,

815.text: indeed this is the observation. There's a gradual

818.text: shortening of telomeres, and eventually the cells cease to

821.text: divide. So this is seen in cancer cells in culture treated

824.text: with such an inhibitor. Now I've put a noted point up here:

830.text: but you're still keeping the telomerase ribonucleoprotein

835.text: (RNP) level high. You're not depleting the cells of the

840.text: enzyme, you are simply rendering that enzyme inactive.

847.text: And I make that distinction because of the next results I

850.text: want to tell you about. So, what was observed was quite

857.text: surprising. If one depleted telomerase, and the particular

862.text: way to knock the telomerase RNA down, then one found

866.text: there was a very rapid effect on human cancer cells. One

870.text: didn't see the long delay ensuing before the effect was

877.text: observed. So, now I'll tell you about those experiments.

882.text: So, reminding you again, here's human telomerase, it's

885.text: copying its RNA template, and of course the enzyme has

890.text: the TERT protein and the telomerase RNA, and it's the

894.text: RNA that is going to be depleted in these experiments.

899.text: How's the RNA depleted? A now commonly used

902.text: technique, which is called a knockdown using RNA

906.text: interference. Now the particular technique was to express

911.text: from a lentiviral vector, which you can introduce efficiently

916.text: into cells, a particular sequence which forms a double-

921.text: stranded RNA, and I've just shown the corresponding

923.text: DNA sequence here, and that double-stranded RNA can

927.text: interact with a cellular RNA that matches its sequence,

932.text: and eventually cause the breakdown of that RNA

937.text: through a complicated process known as RNA

939.text: interference. And so, siRNA refers to "short interfering

944.text: RNA," because such a short interfering RNA, which

949.text: involves introducing two strands of RNA complementary

953.text: to the target RNA, that is what causes the breakdown to

958.text: occur. Now when we did this experiment, so here's a

961.text: control where we're looking at a reference amount, here's

964.text: the telomerase RNA, one found that in fact the method of

969.text: introducing such a short interfering RNA by this kind of

974.text: construct here (the details don't matter), one could in fact

978.text: quite efficiently knock down the telomerase RNA in

982.text: human cancer cells grown in culture, for example, in

985.text: these breast cancer cells grown in culture. And so one

990.text: could knock it down almost down to about 10-12% of the

996.text: original level that one sees in the controls. So what

1001.text: happens then? Now, if what I had told you was the case,

1007.text: that we knock down the telomerase, then we would

1009.text: expect to have to wait for a long time for the telomeres to

1013.text: get short enough, if that were the only thing going on,

1017.text: then we would have to wait before we saw any effect.

1019.text: But right away, there was an effect on the growth of the

1022.text: cells. Now just to put this into perspective here, I'll just

1027.text: walk you through a couple of graphs. Here's the controls

1030.text: of two kinds, and this is the number of cells here. And so

1034.text: what you can see is that the cell number goes up and up

1067.text: in which, here's the empty vector, here is the short

1086.text: And so a great many control experiments were done to

1157.text: Now, one of the things that is very important in human

1161.text: cells to respond to DNA damage such as certain kinds of

1177.text: lines that are otherwise isogenic. This is a colon cancer

1190.text: In this otherwise isogenic cell line lacking p53 but

1196.text: otherwise the same, this response is quantitatively the

1205.text: damage response, and in fact we did not see DNA

1208.text: damage response genes being induced here. We looked

1214.text: at the telomeres by some molecular probing mechanisms
